triples.evidence: In MATLAB, the main tool for simulating this is the Radon transform function, simply called radon.
So when you hear me say “parallel-beam CT,” think of it as collecting straight, evenly spaced rays, rotating around the object, and storing all of that information in a sinogram.

In MATLAB, the main tool for simulating this is the Radon transform function, simply called radon. This function takes an image-our phantom-and generates its parallel-beam projections at different rotation angles.
In MATLAB, the main tool for simulating this is the Radon transform function, simply called radon.
MATLAB's radon function gives us exactly that.
Each projection corresponds to summing the values of the image pixels along those parallel paths.
triples.o: summing the values of the image pixels along those parallel paths
